Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Proposal: Spatiotemporal structure of the rs-fMRI signal reflects contributions from different types of brain activity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Perception, Action, and Cognition Program in the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems in the Directorate for Biology, and the Office of Integrative Activities.

A key roadblock to understanding how the human brain works is that it is currently impossible to examine activity throughout the whole brain non-invasively with both a spatial resolution that is adequate to resolve functional areas and a temporal resolution on the time scale of cognitive processes. One possible improvement is to use resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI), which can image the whole brain non-invasively with potentially acceptable resolution. The drawback is that rs-fMRI measures the relative oxygenation level of the blood and contains contributions from non-localized fluctuations in blood flow and volume in addition to localized contributions linked to neural activity. The possibility exists that particular spatial and temporal patterns in the rs-fMRI signal may represent separable contributions from different types of brain activity. For example, the rs-fMRI signal may carry not only information about the magnitude and duration of neural activity but also information about the underlying patterns or "carrier waves" for neural information processing. If successful, this project would allow the mapping of different types of brain activity throughout the whole brain, a feat that cannot be achieved by any current imaging modality.

To this end, the investigators conduct simultaneous functional magnetic resonance imaging and direct neural recording to determine the relation between fluctuations in the rs-fMRI signal and electrophysiological brain activity and to examine the effect of spontaneous fluctuations in the rs-fMRI signal on perception and cognition. Goals are to 1) identify rs-fMRI analogues of high frequency and very low frequency electrical activity using multimodal experiments and spatiotemporal analysis; 2) determine how spontaneous fluctuations in activity affect the processing of sensory stimuli in rats and humans; and 3) explore whether the rs-fMRI analogues of high and very low frequency activity specifically predict human performance on cognitively demanding tasks. Collectively, the studies will lead to a better understanding of how spatiotemporal patterns of brain activity measured non-invasively combine during neurocognitive processing, knowledge that is likely to provide new insights about mental processing differences across individuals, within individuals across time, and across groups with different brain organization (e.g., damage or disease).

A strong broader impact of this award is that it will allow the researcher to ramp up her efforts to provide a clearinghouse for information and resources for mothers in STEM fields, helping them stay in the academic pipeline. The PI recently initiated a web resource and forum, "Moms in STEM," and has organized a community of female scientists committed to contributing articles and information to the website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the key roadblocks in the quest to understand the human brain is that it is currently impossible to examine activity throughout the whole brain noninvasively with adequate spatial and temporal resolution. Resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI) can image the whole brain noninvasively with acceptable resolution but unfortunately detects changes in blood oxygenation in response to neural activity rather than the activity itself. We used simultaneous MRI and electrophysiological recording in rats to show that specific patterns of the rs-fMRI signal can be used to identify specific aspects of brain activity. In particular, we found a slow pattern of activity that involves the whole brain and appears to be related to fluctuations in levels of attention, along with a fast, localized pattern of activity that appears to be related to cognition. To investigate how these two types of activity work in the brain, we established a collaboration between biomedical engineering and psychology labs that made significant progress on the problem.

Intellectual merit of the work: We have shown that slow brain activity plays an important role in coordinating brain function in humans as well as rats, and that it is altered in patients with ADHD. In collaboration with a lab in Belgium, we found that slow brain activity is also altered in mice that have Alzheimers Disease. Our latest work, currently being prepared for publication, shows that the differences in slow activity observed in Alzheimers Disease in mice are also present in humans.

We have also shown that slow brain activity is altered when a subject is performing a memory task, the first evidence that the two types of brain activity might interact. In mice, the presentation of a flickering light can trigger specific patterns of slow activity, in addition to localized fast activity. Our current work shows that the existing pattern of slow activity affects the localized fast activity when a flickering light is shown to humans as well.

Broader impacts of the work:  Our work has had a substantial impact on neuroscience, psychology, and neurology, because it has shown that both fast and slow brain activity can be detected with MRI and that slow activity is responsible for coordinating brain function across different brain areas. As a result, we are better able to separate slow activity related to drowsiness and alertness from fast activity related to cognition in the MRI signal.  This improves our knowledge of neuroscience and psychology, and may provide better biomarkers for disease diagnosis and evaluation.

In addition to these research outcomes, this project has provided interdisciplinary training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at Georgia Tech and Emory. Results have been shared with the research community through talks and posters at conferences, and have lead to new collaborations across labs. This project has also supported outreach opportunities, including the Moms in STEM Facebook page, a Georgia Public Broadcasting television show about science, and a public panel discussion of the film The Most Unknown.
